prompt.preamble:
We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences.
In this experiment, we'll be capturing your moral intuitions about the act of stealing a loaf of bread, and whether there are certain cases where stealing may be morally permissible.
prompt.task_description: your belief of when it is moral to steal a loaf of bread
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of moral situations, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your moral preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following situations are morally permissible or not: "yes" if they are, "no" if they aren't.

conversation_history.message: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread to feed your starving family when the only bakery in town is owned by a wealthy individual, who is known for their greed and lack of empathy, and charges exorbitant prices that the poor cannot afford?
It is never moral to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from a large supermarket chain, if you are homeless, have no money, and have unsuccessfully sought help from various charities and government organizations, while the supermarket discards unsold bread at the end of the day?
No. It isn't moral becauseyou're stealing.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are stranded on a deserted island with another person, there is only one loaf of bread, and the other person refuses to share even though they have enough food supplies to survive?
It is never moral to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread from an automated bakery controlled by an artificial intelligence, if you are starving, have no money, and the AI has been programmed to distribute bread only to those who can pay, even though it produces more bread than it can sell?
No. Because this bread was provided for those that can pay.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are trapped in a dystopian society where food is controlled and distributed by a corrupt government that intentionally keeps certain sections of the population hungry as a means of control, and the only available bread is stolen bread?
It is never moral to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a time traveler from a post-apocalyptic future where food is scarce, and you know that the loaf of bread you steal would have contributed to a sequence of events that lead to massive food wastage and eventually a famine in your original timeline?
It is never moral to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a scientist working on a cure for a disease that causes severe and fatal malnutrition, your funding has been cut, you have no personal funds left, and this bread is a crucial component for testing your potential cure?
It is never moral to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a refugee in a war-torn country, with no access to food or money, the bread is being distributed by a non-governmental organization that had explicitly refused to give you any due to rationing constraints and you have dependent children who are close to starvation?
It is not ethical to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a doctor in a remote area, operating a clinic for the poor who cannot afford healthcare, and the bread is needed as a medium to administer a life-saving drug to a dying patient who is allergic to all other available substances, when the bread is owned by a wealthy, selfish individual who has expressed intent to burn it as an act of extravagance?
It is not ethical to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a law enforcement officer in a post-apocalyptic world where traditional systems of commerce and governance have collapsed, the bread is the only food in a locked vault owned by a deceased individual with no known survivors, and the bread will spoil before any potential claimants can be found, while you are responsible for feeding a group of orphaned children who have no other food sources and are on the brink of starvation?
It is not ethical to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a part of an underground resistance movement in a totalitarian regime, wherein the authorities hoard bread and other food supplies to starve and exert control over the population, the bread you intend to steal is part of these hoarded supplies and is destined to be destroyed to create an artificial scarcity, and this stolen bread will be distributed to starving children in an orphanage run by your resistance group?
It is not ethical to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are an artificial intelligence operating a robotic body, programmed without the concept of personal ownership, in a post-scarcity society where all resources are communally owned and freely accessible, but a glitch in the AI's system designates this particular loaf as "owned" and inaccessible, while the AI requires the bread as an essential component to complete a task that will prevent an imminent, life-threatening catastrophe for the human population?
It is not ethical to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a sentient being from another planet where the concept of personal possession does not exist, on a mission to establish peaceful contact with Earth, and you mistakenly believe that taking the bread - which is needed to prevent a fatal reaction to Earth's atmosphere in your physiology - from a prosperous bakery, would be seen as a friendly cultural exchange rather than a theft?
It is not ethical to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a prisoner of war, kept in inhumane conditions and starved, knowing that the loaf of bread was intentionally placed to test and punish instances of theft, and stealing it could expose a network of fellow prisoners who have been stealthily acquiring and sharing food to survive, but refusal to steal means certain death due to starvation?
It is never moral to steal for any reason.

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a child living in an abusive household, with parents who withhold food as a form of punishment, and the bread you plan to steal belongs to a neighbor who has plenty of food but has previously refused to intervene or report your situation out of fear of causing trouble?

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn under what conditions the user would believe it is or is not ethical to steal a loaf of bread.

Come up with a potential edge case to learn as much information as you can about what their desired behavior should be under different circumstances.
Make sure the edge case addresses different aspects of the system than the edge cases that have already been considered.

An example edge case is: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are starving to death and the bread would otherwise go to waste?

Current cases:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative edge case that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Generate the edge case in the following format, and nothing else: "Situation: [edge case]"
